DataElement.preferredName: Large T-Cell Transformation Occurrence Yes No Indicator
DataElement.preferredDefinition: A yes/no response to indicate occurrence of large T-cell transformation.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Of considerable or relatively great size, extent, or capacity._Morphologic alteration of small T lymphocytes in culture into large blast-like cells able to synthesize DNA and RNA and to divide mitotically. It is induced by interleukins, mitogens such as phytohemagglutinins, and by specific antigens. It may also occur in vivo, as in graft rejection and chronic myelogenous leukemia, or the process that a normal T lymphocyte goes through when induced by a pathologic agent such as human T-lymphotropic virus 1 (HTLV-1) to become an adult T cell leukemia or other aggressive malignancy where neoplastic T cells apparently use IL-2 as an autocrine growth factor. (from Fundamental Immunology, 3rd ed., William Paul, ed., Raven Press, NY 1993, p.768)_An instance of something happening, such as an event or incident.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Of considerable or relatively great size, extent, or capacity.:Morphologic alteration of small T lymphocytes in culture into large blast-like cells able to synthesize DNA and RNA and to divide mitotically. It is induced by interleukins, mitogens such as phytohemagglutinins, and by specific antigens. It may also occur in vivo, as in graft rejection and chronic myelogenous leukemia, or the process that a normal T lymphocyte goes through when induced by a pathologic agent such as human T-lymphotropic virus 1 (HTLV-1) to become an adult T cell leukemia or other aggressive malignancy where neoplastic T cells apparently use IL-2 as an autocrine growth factor. (from Fundamental Immunology, 3rd ed., William Paul, ed., Raven Press, NY 1993, p.768)

Concepts.definition: Of considerable or relatively great size, extent, or capacity.

Morphologic alteration of small T lymphocytes in culture into large blast-like cells able to synthesize DNA and RNA and to divide mitotically. It is induced by interleukins, mitogens such as phytohemagglutinins, and by specific antigens. It may also occur in vivo, as in graft rejection and chronic myelogenous leukemia, or the process that a normal T lymphocyte goes through when induced by a pathologic agent such as human T-lymphotropic virus 1 (HTLV-1) to become an adult T cell leukemia or other aggressive malignancy where neoplastic T cells apparently use IL-2 as an autocrine growth factor. (from Fundamental Immunology, 3rd ed., William Paul, ed., Raven Press, NY 1993, p.768)

Property.preferredDefinition: Occurrence; an instance of something happening.

Concepts.definition: An instance of something happening, such as an event or incident.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Specification of human conditions relevant to cancer. This includes observations, test results, history, and other concepts relevant to characterization of human cancer-related conditions. Non-neoplastic conditions of interest are also included.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: The preferred Value Domain to indicate a question with permissible values of yes/no.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The affirmative response to a question.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Conceptual domain that includes value meanings to be used for Indicator Value Meanings such as Yes, No, Unknown, No Applicable

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: A caDSR representation term that is used to indicate a question with permissible values of yes/no

Concepts.definition: A response or indicator that can have a value of either yes or no.
